AUSTRALIA

BHP (BHP AT)
- Escondida mine workers union stated that Co. new wage offer was unacceptable and that they will proceed with a strike unless there is a better offer. (Newswires)

Resolute Mining (RSG AT)
- Co. received environmental clearance to recommission the Bibiani underground mine and processing facility. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO AT)
- Co. has signed a AUD 4.7bln non-binding agreement with Indonesia regarding the Co.’s exit from the Grasberg copper mine. (Newswires)


 

JAPAN

Fast Retailing (9983 JT)
- Co. 9-month net JPY 148.3bln vs. Prev. JPY 120.1bln Y/Y, rev. JPY 1.70tln vs. Prev. JPY 1.48tln Y/Y, while Q3 oper. profit also topped estimates after increasing 36% and the Co. affirmed its outlook. (Newswires)

- FTC issued a cease and desist order to the Co. and Seven & I (3382 JT) unit Sogo & Seibu concerning uniform sales to All Nippon Airways (9202 JT). (Newswires)

Nomura Holdings (8604 JT)

Yamato Holdings (9064 JT)
- Co. is expected to post Q1 oper. profit of around JPY 5.0bln vs. Prev. loss JPY 10.0bln Y/Y. (Nikkei)

Yaskawa Electric (6506 JT)
- Co. Q1 net JPY 15.7bln vs. Prev. JPY 9.8bln Y/Y. (Newswires)


SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Heavy (009540 KS)

Samsung Biologics (207940 KS)
- South Korea financial regulator alleged that Co. violated accounting rules and recommended executives be dismissed and a referral to prosecutors. (Newswires)  

Other News

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS:
content:
ASIA

Chinese Commerce Ministry stated that so far they have had no contact with the US about restarting negotiations. Elsewhere, there were also comments from US President Trump that US is in a nasty trade battle with China but added they will negotiate a fair trade deal if that's possible and that he expects something very good with China in the end. (Newswires)

UK

UK published its Brexit White Paper which stated there will be more barriers to the UK's access to the EU's market and that a facilitated customs arrangement will be as if Britain was in a combined territory with the EU. The White Paper also plans to diverge from EU rules for services which means a lower level of access after Brexit and abandons the idea of mutual recognition for financial services, while it will end the free movement of people and the direct jurisdiction of the European Court of Justice over Britain post-Brexit. (Newswires)

EU chief Brexit negotiator Barnier will discuss White Paper with member states and debate with the UK next week, while there were also reports the European Parliament's Brexit Steering Group welcomed the UK's White Paper, particularly that the UK is proposing an Association Agreement. (Newswires)

US President Trump is said to warn UK PM May that a soft Brexit would probably kill potential future trade deal between UK and US as they would be dealing with EU instead of UK. (The Sun)
 


EU

ECB minutes stated that the progress toward a sustained adjustment of inflation path is substantial and are confident that adjustment would continue. ECB minutes added that open ended character of interest rate guidance should be emphasized and that given the uncertainty, it is prudent to leave the end of QE conditional on incoming data. Furthermore, the minutes also noted that policymakers were unanimous in support of policy proposals. (Newswires)

French finance minister Le Maire said if the US trade war persists, EU will take new decisions and commented that specific deal on autos with the US threatens jobs. (Newswires)


US President Trump said he is in talks with the EU and will meet them next week on trade. (Newswires)
 

US

Fed’s Powell (Chair, Neutral) reiterated the Fed is hearing concerns regarding trade wars and that sustained high tariffs could be a negative for the economy. Furthermore, Powell said low wage growth is a puzzle, but added the labour market is strong by any measure and the US economy is in a really good place. (Marketplace)

Fed's Mester (Voter, Hawk) said the US economy justifies 2 more rate hikes this year. (Newswires)

Fed’s Harker (Non-Voter, Dove) stated he welcomes 4 rate hikes this year if inflation accelerates, but added he still sees 3 hikes this year and that the Fed rate hikes could lift policy rate to 3.00%-3.25%. Furthermore, Harker said inflation is moving towards the 2% target and noted the inflation goal is symmetric and is comfortable moving to 2.5%. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said many of the US trade talks with China have broken down, while he earlier commented that the US is available to discuss with China to the extent that the country wants to make changes on trade and that the US is very focused on retaliatory trade measures and how to resolve them. Furthermore, Mnuchin also commented that NAFTA negotiations are a priority following Mexico’s elections. (Newswires)

US CPI MM, SA (Jun) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%). (Newswires)
US CPI YY, NSA (Jun) 2.9% vs. Exp. 2.9% (Prev. 2.8%)


MARKET RECAP

Delta (DAL) beat on the top and bottom lines, hiked its dividend by 1%, though cut guidance; quarterly profits were hit by rises in fuel costs, though DAL said it has had early success in addressing these. Papa John’s (PZZA) rose after founder and President stepped-down after allegedly using a racial slur on a media call. ConocoPhilips (COP) boosted its share buyback authorisation by $9bln taking it to $15bln, and is making progress in trimming debt. Tesla (TSLA) was lower after a downgrade at UBS, and news that it hit 200k cars produced, meaning lower tax credit for buyers. In M&A news, Semiconductor Broadcom (AVGO) was hit as it nears a deal to buy CA Technologies (CA) for almost $19bln, it’s first major M&A since the Trump Administration blocked its $117bln deal to buy Qualcomm (QCOM) in March; investors were sceptical, with AVGO down 14%, though CA rose 18%. The battle for SKY LN assets has picked up after Comcast (CMCSA) raised its offer to $34bln; the UK government ok’d Fox’s (FOXA) remedies for its Sky bid, clearing the path for Fox/Comcast to battle it out. Elsewhere, EU antitrust regulators are set to approve the Linde (LIN GY)-Praxair (PX) $83bln merger, sources reported. Aetna (AET) and CVS Health (CVS) were up on reports that the DOJ will not challenge the merger of the two, according to research firm Reorg. Wallmart (WMT) is considering a bid from Capital One Financial (COF) for its credit card business, sending COF higher on Thursday, while Walmart's current partner Synchrony (SYF) fell. SPX +0.9% at 2798, NDX +1.7% at 7366, DJI +0.9% at 24926.

The complex moved sideways on Thursday. The yield curve modestly bear-flattened with most of the yields higher by under 2bps. Major curve spreads saw another session of flattening by c.1bps; 2s10s fell to as low as 25bps for another fresh low, while 2s30s and 5s30s also narrowed by 2bps and 1bps respectively. US 10YR T-notes futures (u8) settled 3 ticks lower at 120-05.

US MARKET WRAP - 12 July 2018: Markets go back to ignoring trade wars
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries flat, crude mixed, Dollar Index flat.
* REAR-VIEW: Mnuchin says most talks with China have broken down; ECB minutes show broad support for tapering; US CPI mostly in line; Fed chair Powell reveals little new.
* COMING-UP: Chinese Trade Balance, Japanese Industrial Output, US University of Michigan Sentiment, BoE's Cunliffe, Fed's Bostic and ECB's De Guindos; WFC, PNC, JPM and C earnings.

* TRADE: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said the US is very focused on retaliatory trade measures and how to resolve them, adding that the US is monitoring the impact of its trade policies. He also said that he is available to discuss trade with the Chinese, should they want to, saying that the Trump administration is focussed on free and fair trade, but added many of the US trade talks with China have broken down. Chinese vice trade minister Wang, who on Wednesday called for talks to de-escalate trade tensions, said talks would be pointless if the US constantly keeps chopping and changing its position. Mnuchin, meanwhile, will visit the EU later this month for talks with the EU’s Juncker. On NAFTA, Mnuchin said negotiations are a big priority now that Mexico’s elections are out of the way. Elsewhere, French finance minister Le Maire says if the US trade war persists, EU will take new decisions, adding that specific deal on autos with the US threatens jobs.

* ECB: The accounts of its June meeting showed broad support for a dovish approach to tapering asset purchases and bring QE to an end this year, as well as to introduce forward guidance on rates to anchor expectations of the ECB’s first rate hike of the cycle. ING said the assessment of the outlook for the economy showed remarkable optimism, with the central bank confident that the expansion will remain solid and broad-based, continuing at an above potential pace, though the ECB stated that downside risks could be presented by global factors. “Reading between the lines of the minutes, the ECB tries to give the impression that the de-facto announcement of an end to QE at the June meeting was the most normal thing in the world, a natural evolution of previous recalibrations,” ING said. “While back in June not everyone would have agreed with the ECB, the reactions after the announcement seem to prove the ECB right. With hindsight.” ING believes the ECB will find it difficult to end QE this year given the risks, but said that the broad majority of ECB members seems determined to end QE, and would like to return to interest rates as the main policy tool. “This, however, does not necessarily mean that they will be in a hurry to hike rates.”

* FED: Fed chair Powell gave an interview to Marketplace where he rattled off his familiar comments: Fed is hearing concerns regarding trade wars – sustained high tariffs could be a negative for the economy. Powell said low wage growth is a puzzle, but the labour market is strong by any measure, and the US economy is in a really good place. Powell did caution that it would be a policy challenge if inflation were to rise while the economy was weakening. On fiscal policy, Powell said it will likely support the economy over the next three years. Fed's Mester (Hawkish) said the US economy justifies 2 more rate hikes this year. Fed’s Harker (Non-Voter) noted inflation is moving towards the 2% target and defined the inflation goal symmetric; he said he is comfortable with inflation moving to 2.5% He said to welcome 4 rate hikes this year if inflation accelerates though his base case remains for 3 hikes. He believes Fed rate Hikes could lift policy rate to 3% - 3.75% and warned gains in services inflation are something to watch.

* US CPI posted a 0.1% MM gain in June, below expectations of 0.2%, Core CPI was in line at 0.2%. The y/y figures were as expected at 2.9% and 2.3% respectively, with the core at ‘a level equal to its highest increase since prior to the recession’ according to UBS. In the core measures, softer apparel prices and a fall in hotel room rates were offset by higher prices in the used car sector and in medical services. Gasoline prices SA ticked up by 0.5%, moderating from the 3% increase seen in April. Overall the latest release appears to be ‘consistent with continued gradual increase in interest rates’ with the latest release having little effect on the medium-term inflation view, UBS said. Pantheon Macroeconomics, meanwhile, argued that the Fed is hiking rates because of the labour market and not because of the current inflation outlook.

* US WEEKLY CLAIMS: Jobless Claims dropped to 214k, consensus was for 226k, bringing the 4-week moving average to 223k (Prev. 225k) and thus signalling a healthy labour market. The effect of tariffs does not seem to be reflected in the measure just yet though, Pantheon Macroeconomics said, this was cited as a potential factor behind their move higher seen in the previous weeks.

* SPX +0.9% at 2798, NDX +1.7% at 7366, DJI +0.9% at 24926. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals -0.1%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.7%, Energy: +0.2%, Financials: +0.2%, Health Care: +1.1%, Industrials: +1.1%, Materials: +0.2%, Telecoms: +0.5%, Tech: +1.8%, Utilities: +0.1%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Delta (DAL) beat on the top and bottom lines, hiked its dividend by 1%, though cut guidance; quarterly profits were hit by rises in fuel costs, though DAL said it has had early success in addressing these. Papa John’s (PZZA) rose after founder and President stepped-down after allegedly using a racial slur on a media call. ConocoPhilips (COP) boosted its share buyback authorisation by $9bln taking it to $15bln, and is making progress in trimming debt. Tesla (TSLA) was lower after a downgrade at UBS, and news that it hit 200k cars produced, meaning lower tax credit for buyers.

* M&A: Semiconductor Broadcom (AVGO) was hit as it nears a deal to buy CA Technologies (CA) for almost $19bln, it’s first major M&A since the Trump Administration blocked its $117bln deal to buy Qualcomm (QCOM) in March; investors were sceptical, with AVGO down 14%, though CA rose 18%. The battle for SKY LN assets has picked up after Comcast (CMCSA) raised its offer to $34bln; the UK government ok’d Fox’s (FOXA) remedies for its Sky bid, clearing the path for Fox/Comcast to battle it out. Elsewhere, EU antitrust regulators are set to approve the Linde (LIN GY)-Praxair (PX) $83bln merger, sources reported. Aetna (AET) and CVS Health (CVS) were up on reports that the DOJ will not challenge the merger of the two, according to research firm Reorg. Wallmart (WMT) is considering a bid from Capital One Financial (COF) for its credit card business, sending COF higher on Thursday, while Walmart's current partner Synchrony (SYF) fell.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (U8) SETTLES 3 TICKS LOWER AT 120-05. The complex moved sideways on Thursday. The yield curve modestly bear-flattened with most of the yields higher by under 2bps. Major curve spreads saw another session of flattening by c.1bps; 2s10s fell to as low as 25bps for another fresh low, while 2s30s and 5s30s also narrowed by 2bps and 1bps respectively.

* US 30-YEAR AUCTION REVIEW: Thursday’s auction of 30s was fairly average, with metrics close to recent averages; the auction saw a tail of 0.4bps at a high yield of 2.958% (lowest since January), cover was at 2.34x (the lowest since February). Indirects takedown was the lowest since April, leaving dealers the largest since April.

* WTI FUTURES (Q8) SETTLE $0.05 LOWER AT $70.33; BRENT (U8) SETTLES $1.05 HIGHER AT $74.45. Crude prices were mixed, after Wednesday’s slide. While Brent was outperforming, the term structures were moving bearishly, with the front Brent contracts (U8/V8) entering contango briefly, settling at 1 cent (from 7 cents yesterday); for WTI, the Q8/U8 backwardation narrowed by 54 cents. In addition to the chunky supply coming back onto the market from Libya, and ongoing global trade tensions, Reuters’ John Kemp suggested that hedge funds might have been booking profits after a year-long rally. Additionally, there has been some suggestions that the US will allow waivers for countries to import Iranian crude, potentially lessening the impact of a ‘supply crunch’. Brent seemed to look through today’s news from Libya, where the El Feel (with a capacity of 100k+ BPD) was to restart for the first time since February, which Citi says could suggest the rebound in supply could extend beyond simply reversing the impact of the more recent port closures. In its monthly report, the IEA issued fresh warnings that global crude spare capacity is facing risks of being stretched by prolonged supply outages.

* USD: The DXY got to within spitting distance of the 95.00 handle, but found the air thin as it approached the highs and fell back to within a c.94.65-c.94.80 range, slightly lower on the day, with risk appetite tentatively returning on Wednesday. CPI data failed to have a lasting impact on FX/rates. Ahead of next week’s semi-annual testimony, Fed chair Powell stayed off the subject of monetary policy in comments today.

* JPY: There has been much debate about the yen’s supposedly strange behaviour in recent sessions, not reacting/reacting in a delayed fashion to bouts of risk. On Wednesday, a break of the three-year trend resistance around 111.50 has provided the platform for USDJPY to bounce to above 112.50 at one point today. The theory from the folks at UBS is that the market has been short USDJPY in the last couple of weeks in anticipation of a fall in equities; that fall ultimately failed to materialise, and shorts became nervous as the USDJPY approached the 11.40-60 pivot, and once it cleared, it brought about a short-covering squeeze higher. From a technical perspective, UBS notes that key levels of resistance now are around 112.50 and 113.00, and has suggested longs near 111.60-80 targeting those levels.

* GBP: Cable has managed to return to the 1.3220 area once again, and has done little in the last few sessions to break either below that level, or about meaningfully above 1.3240. Desks still are focusing on downside vulnerabilities, with Scotia pointing out that Sterling’s failure against the 40-day moving average earlier in the week leaves the pound looking prone to a little more softness. Intraday trend momentum signals are aligned negatively, Scotia said, but the longer run signals are flat (daily) and weekly price action hints at some potential for a broader base to develop, and it looks for losses to stabilize between 1.3050/1.3150. Like at the BOE HQ, politics are likely to be the driving factor of sterling moves, more than economic fundamentals. ING has argued that if the EU is comforted by the latest White Paper, we could see GBP up to 1.33-1.34 (which some policymakers have tentatively suggested), and on the flip side, if ‘no deal’ Brexit probabilities pick up, a slide beneath 1.30 could be on the cards.

* AUD: A better risk tone and stabilisation in commodities helped the likes of the Aussie pare back some of Wednesday’s slide, while AUDJPY jumped to the highest since mid-June, helped by rising stocks, and yen declines. With that said, traders are cognizant of trade war risks, and some desks prefer to look to play the Aussie to the downside as it hits recent highs, with any escalation of trade wars likely to lend strength to the USD, to the Aussie’s detriment; the RBA and Fed also are on divergent courses, which would support AUDUSD downside, analysts have said.

subject: AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 14bln of 30-year bonds at 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content: The Treasury will this week auction USD 69bln in new supply (USD 33bln of 3-year notes on Tuesday, USD 22bln 10-year reopening on Wednesday, USD 14bln of reopened 30-year bonds on Thursday). USD 28.7bln in new cash will be raised, given the USD 40.3bln maturing mid-month, according to TD Securities. Recent auctions in the 30-year sector have been well-received, with the last four auctions all stopping-through (only three of the last 12 30-year auctions has seen a tail, suggesting that demand remains firm for long-dated debt). Analysts at SocGen suggest that the decent performance in the long-end can be attributed to corporations rushing to increase their pension plan contributions before the September deadline, to take advantage of higher tax deductions. However, there are some negatives: benchmark 30-year yields are beneath the stop-out rate of the last five auctions, which SocGen says will likely warrant some concession heading into Thursday’s sale. Additionally, the bank argues that the sector remains rich on the curve, with 5s30s near the lowest levels in over a decade. On the flip side, current 30s are cheap on the spline versus the older 30s relative to the previous two auction cycles.

Daily FX Wrap: Buck balks at more benign US wage data, and m/m CPI
content:
DXY

The index has continued its steady rebound from post-NFP lows amidst broad Dollar gains vs G10 counterparts and got to within a whisker of the 95.000 handle before fading on tame real earnings data and sub-forecast m/m headline inflation. DXY currently back down around 94.750.

CHF/JPY  

A rather belated decline in the Franc if the rationale was less risk aversion around US-China trade wars and/or NATO, but nevertheless the move was pronounced vs both the Usd and Eur as the former rallied over parity and the cross climbed to 1.1700. Stop buying was reported in the latter from 1.1660 upward, while the headline pair hit a ytd peak at 1.0057 on May 10. Conversely, the Jpy pared some losses vs the Greenback having been the big underperformer overnight to trade back over 112.50 vs 112.60 at one stage, although the safe-haven remains vulnerable to any further improvement in overall sentiment.

AUD/CAD/NZD

All ending Thursday’s session on the front foot vs their US peer, with the Aud retesting 0.7400, Loonie down towards the base of a 1.3150-1.3220 range and not adversely impacted by a stagnant Canadian new homes price index, while the Kiwi marginally extended its wingspan to touch 0.6780.

GBP  

Another beneficiary of the post-US data Usd downturn as Cable climbed to 1.3245 and largely shrugged off the Brexit White Paper that was largely as leaked via the UK press or reported via other outlets ahead of its official publication.

EUR

Choppy trade within 1.1650-95 parameters vs the Usd, but the single currency recovering from a post-ECB minutes dip (main takeaway a desire to underline the open-ended nature of policy guidance) to sit around the base of hefty option expiry interest situated between 1.1675 and 1.1700 (2.5 bn in total).

SEK

An outperformer vs its Nok rival and the Eur on a softer than expected Swedish CPIF y/y print and dovish elements of the latest Riksbank minutes (ie Jansson’s view that the timing of a rate hike, signalled for approaching the end of 2018, is more likely to be pushed back than brought forward). Nok/Sek up near 1.0950 and Eur/Sek close to 10.3700.

subject: Daily US Equity Opening News 12 July 2018: Fox (FOXA)/Comcast (CMCSA) to battle for Sky (SKY LN); Delta (DAL) beats on top and bottom lines; ConocoPhilips (COP) boosts buybacks
content:
12th July 2018

Earnings

  • Delta Air Lines (DAL) – Reports Q4 EPS at 1.77 (USD) beating expectations of 1.72, revenue beat at 11.8bln (versus an expected 11.67bln), and raised its dividend by 15% to 35 cents. The airline cuts guidance for FY EPS to 5.35-5.70 (previously 6.35-6.70). Q2 TRASM was up 4.6%. Delta’s quarterly profit was down 13.6% as operating expenses rose 39% due to the rise in fuel costs; DAL did say it has seen early success in addressing the fuel cost increase, and has offset two-thirds of the impact in the June quarter. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Apple (AAPL) – TF International Securities in a note said Apple is planning an 11-inch iPad Pro, a watch and an updated Mac in its fall hardware line up. Separately, in a filing against former engineer accused of stealing secrets, the Tech giant said 5,000 people had access to information on its autonomy Project Titan. Separately, Apple announces MacBook Pro pricing: 13-inch at USD 1799 and 15-inch USD 2399. (Newswires)
  • Boeing (BA) – Amid the aerospace and defence company’s tie-up with Embraer (ERJ), ERJ is reportedly counting on the public-sector shareholders’ vote to top any potential objections from investors about the tie-up with Boeing. Separately, Boeing won a USD 131mln modification to a contract for the procurement of four MH-47G Block II airplane. (Newswires)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – The bank and cable maker Prysmian (and eight other cable companies) have lost their challenge against a EUR 302mln EU cartel fine. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – The supermarket chain is seeking to sell its Japanese unit Seiyu, could fetch USD 4.5bln. Walmart is said to have approached major retailers and private equity firms about the possibility of a deal, though Nikkei reports that it might find difficulties in finding a partner. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Colgate-Palmolive (CL) – The household product company promotes Noel Wallace to the position of President and chief operations officer. (Newswires)
  • ConocoPhillips (COP) – The O&G E&P company expands its 2018 share buyback facility by USD 1bln, taking it to USD3bln; it also boosts the previously announced share buyback authorisation by USD 9bln, taking it to a total of USD 15bln. COP says it has achieved its USD 15bln debt target plan significantly ahead of schedule, and paid down USD 2.1bln of its balance sheet debt in Q2. (Newswires)
  • Comcast (CMCSA)/Twenty-First Century Fox (FOXA) – Cable and satellite operator Comcast (CMCSA) increases its superior cash offer for Sky (SKY LN) to USD 34bln (GBP 14.75/shr) and says its offer has been recommended by the Sky Independent Committee of Directors. Additionally, the UK government has accepted Fox's (FOXA) remedies for Sky (SKY LN) bid clearing the way for a Fox/Comcast battle. (Newswires)
  • Costco (COST) – The retail wholesaler reported same store sales ex-items rose 6% in June, up 11.7% Y/Y. (Newswires)
  • Freeport McMoRan (FCX) – Rio Tinto (RIO), PT Indonesia Asahan Aluminium, and Freeport McMoran (FCX) sign a non-binding agreement detailing the proposed principal terms for the sale of Rio Tinto's entire interest in Grasberg to Inalum, Indonesia's state mining company, for USD 3.5bln. Rio had a JV with Freeport, the operator of Grasberg, for a 40% share of Grasberg’s production above specific levels until 2021, as well as 40% of all production after 2021. (Newswires)
  • L Brands (LB) – Same store sales rose by 3% in June, net sales rose 5.7% Y/Y. (Newswires)
  • Praxair (PX) – Germany’s Messer Group is the preferred bidder for Linde’s (LIN GY) North American business, which it is required to sell in order to complete the USD 83bln between Linde and Praxair. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Broadcom (AVGO) – The semiconductor name is near a deal to buy CA Technologies for USD 44.50/shr (USD 18.9bln total, representing a premium of around 6%), it’s first major M&A since the Trump Administration blocked its USD 117bln deal to buy Qualcomm in March. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media company will give full access to data on its 2.2bln users to identify areas of research about the effects of social media on elections and democracy. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – A former technician for the automaker has filed a whistle blower complaint with the SEC alleging that Tesla used dangerous batteries and lied to investors. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • GoPro (GPRO) – Co. said says it has sold over 30mln HERO cameras since its debut in 2009; GoPro cameras have been the best-selling camera of any type for 17 consecutive quarters in North America. (Newswires)
  • Papa John’s (PZZA) – The fast food outlet announces the resignation of John Schnatter as Chairman and founder. Co. will appoint a new chairman in the coming weeks. (Newswires)
  • Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) – Starboard Value has cut its stake in the tech firm to 8.6% from 10.5%. (Newswires)
  • Spirit Airlines (SAVE) – Airline reports Q2 TRASM declined by 6.8% (versus guidance made in April of a decline of 6.5% to 7.5%); Q2 capacity rose 30.5% versus last year (it guided 29% in April). (Newswires)
  • Weatherford International (WFT) – The O&G services company is to sell its drilling operations in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Algeria for USD 287.5mln to ADES International Holding. Transaction will close in H2 2018 subject to regulatory approval. (Newswires)
  • Zoegenix (ZGNX) – Co. says primary endpoint achieved in a second Phase 3 clinical trial of ZX008 for the treatment of children with Dravet syndrome. (Newswires)

Fixed and FX latest: bonds fixated, but Usd firmer again
content: Core debt has been pretty static for a while, but the DXY has nudged a bit nearer to 95.000 amidst all round Dollar buying and a leg-up around midday that suggests some bids from early birds arriving to work in the US. Eur/Usd has pulled back a bit further from 1.1700 to 1.1650 with the single currency not deriving any support from dovish-leaning ECB minutes, but perhaps not will to completely let go or lose sight of mega option expiry interest between 1.1675-1.1700 (2.5 bn approximately). Meanwhile, Cable looks tied to the 1.3200 handle with very little reaction to the UK White Paper, but Usd/Jpy did absorb some offers at 112.50 on its way up to circa 112.60 before easing back a bit. Next up, US CPI and jobless claims, with the former perhaps more likely to give the Usd another lift or deflate sentiment.

US President Trump says we are in a nasty trade battle with China, but will negotiate a fair trade deal if that's possible, and he expects something very good with China in the end

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 12th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Mixed reports that US President Trump is to exit NATO after the Chinese Commerce Ministry rubbished suggestions that there had been contact with the US on trade
  • Choppy trade in equities while commodities find some relief after sharp losses in Wednesday’s trade
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, ECB minutes, US CPI, weekly jobs figures, supply from the US

  • ASIA

    Asian equity markets shrugged off the energy-led declines in US and traded higher across the board with short covering in the region seen after the prior day’s trade-related losses. ASX 200 (+0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) were positive in which the latter coat-tailed on upside in USD/JPY and with Softbank among the biggest gainers after US investment fund Tiger Global took a stake of over USD 1bln in the Co., while broad gains were also seen in Australia aside from commodity-related sectors following recent weakness in the complex including a near-5% drop in crude. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.1%) conformed to the improved risk tone after the PBoC conducted repo operations for the 1st time in over a week and amid continued positive rhetoric regarding A-shares valuations which were said to be at historic lows. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with price action uneventful throughout the session amid focus on riskier assets and with the 20yr auction results largely ignored, despite showing firmer demand and higher accepted prices than previous.       

    PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

    PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6726 (Prev. 6.6234)

    White House aide stated that US has conducted several high-level talks with China and are open to further discussions. However, there were later conflicting reports that talks between US-China have collapsed following the fresh tariff list and that there were no immediate plans to restart discussions. Thereafter, in early European trade the Chinese Commerce Ministry said that so far they have had no contact with the US about restarting negotiations (Newswires/Twitter)

    Bank of Korea kept the 7-Day Repo Rate unchanged at 1.50% as expected, with the decision not unanimous as board member Lee Il-Houng dissented. BoK Governor Lee commented that GDP growth forecast for 2018 was lowered to 2.9% from 3.0% and stated that recent depreciation in KRW against USD was rapid. (Newswires)

    EU/UK/US

    UK PM May is said to propose a looser relationship with the EU regarding financial services which would reduce access to the European market for UK-based financial firms post-Brexit. (FT) Hardline Tory Brexiters are looking to try to force UK PM May to publish a rival draft of the white paper drawn up by David Davis in the run-up to last week’s Chequers summit, which Downing Street ditched. (Guardian)

    UK RICS Housing Survey (Jun) 2 vs. Exp. -4 (Prev. -3). (Newswires)

    US President Trump was reportedly threatening to withdraw from NATO, as according to sources, but this was denied later in trade, with the same source saying that Trump had criticized the alliance today in an unscheduled session. In a press conference US President Trump said he is in talks with the EU and will meet them next week on trade, adding their commitment to NATO is very strong (Newswires)

    Riksbank minutes: Measures of underlying inflation indicate that inflationary pressures are still moderate, which, according to several members, raises questions about the development of inflation in the long-run. (Newswires)

    CENTRAL BANKS

    Fed's Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said despite strength in equities and house prices, he is not seeing risk taking in financial system of last decade and stated that employers struggling to fill job vacancies which signals a strong economy. (Newswires)

    EQUITIES

    European equities are currently mixed, with the Euro Stoxx 50 essentially flat on the day and consolidating following the losses seen in yesterday’s trade. Equities were slightly choppy amid source reports suggesting that US President Trump was criticising NATO and had threatened to drop out, reports thereafter suggested that pulling out is not on the cards.

    The IBEX (-0.2%) and FTSE MIB (-0.3%) are in the red, weighed on by bank stocks with exposure to Turkish assets (BBVA -0.7%) alongside broad-based financial underperformance (UniCredit -1.0%, Banca Generali -1.1%, CaixaBank -1.1%) and possible strike action at Fiat’s (-1.0%) Melfi plant over Cristiano Ronaldo’s transfer cost. Telecom Italia (-1.3%) is also underperforming after a price target cut at Barclays, and is weighing on the telecoms sector, which is currently negative for the day.

    The FTSE is outperforming on the back of betting names such as Paddy Power Betfair (+2.7%) benefitting from England’s exit from the World Cup.

    Updates on Sky (+1.8%) where Comcast have tabled a GBP 26bln offer to buy the co., moving swiftly to trump Fox’s GBP 24.5bln offer earlier in the week.

    FIXED INCOME

    It remains rather begrudging or at least lacking in conviction, but Bunds and Gilts did stretch the upper end of their intraday ranges to 162.68 and 123.09 (+15 and +16 ticks) before topping out again. No real rationale, though this did coincide with a downturn in BTPs and other peripheral bonds, which looks supply-related in part at least. Conversely, US Treasuries remain depressed and close to overnight session lows ahead of a slew of data, highlighted by CPI that may be skewed to the upside vs consensus in wake of Wednesday’s above forecast PPI. Weekly claims also due after last Friday’s mixed NFP report and the last leg of this week’s auctions in the shape of $14 bn 30 year debt. Note also, some Fed speak via Kashkari and Harker.

    FX

    JPY/AUD - Flanking the G10 list of worst and best performers on less investor angst over a full blown US-China trade war even though the latter (via a Commerce Ministry official) has scotched speculation that the 2 sides have been talking already. Short covering also a factor behind the broad bounce in risk assets and resultant reduced demand for safe-havens like the Jpy that finally yielded to pressure below 111.00 vs the Usd, as the pair broke higher and into a fresh range overnight. Stops are said to have been tripped through 111.50 and major trend-line resistance around 111.57 that had been capping the upside, with more triggered when 112.00 was breached on the way to a circa 112.40 peak. Conversely, the Aud has been able to stem further losses and rebound ahead of 0.7350 vs its US counterpart, although the 0.7400 handle remains elusive.

    CHF - Mildly softer vs the Usd as the Franc slips through 0.9950, but still not really behaving like a true port in a currency storm given strict SNB intervention to prevent the highly valued Chf getting too strong.

    NZD/GBP/EUR/CAD - All around 0.1-0.15% up on the Greenback, but rangebound with the Kiwi hovering between 0.6750-75, Cable pivoting 1.3200 and awaiting the Brexit White Paper, Eur/Usd trading just below 1.1700 ahead of the ECB minutes and Loonie straddling 1.3200 having lost all and more of its BoC-inspired strength following the tank in oil prices yesterday.

    SEK/TRY - Sub-forecast Swedish inflation data and Riksbank minutes highlighting dovish dissenting views have undermined the Krona as the Eur cross climbs to 10.3300 from just over 10.2700 at one stage, but the Lira has regained some composure after slumping to a fresh all time low vs the Usd on Wednesday circa 5.0000 amidst comments from Turkey’s new Treasury and Finance Minister ‘assuring’ CBRT independence and reaffirming pledges to pursue policies that will be fiscally prudent, with single digit inflation and structural reform among the other main priorities. Usd/Try back down around 4.8000.

    COMMODITIES

    Oil is recovering this morning after the significant losses seen in yesterday’s trade that was spurred on by trade concerns and increased Libyan production. WTI is up 0.8% and Brent up 1.8% but still well below the levels seen prior to yesterday’s trade, with WTI finding some support at its 100DMA, currently at USD 69.40. IEA maintain their forecast for 2018 global oil demand growth of 1.4mln BPD, say OPEC crude production in June reached a 4-month high of 31.87mln BPD, up 180k BPD (excl. Congo)

    Gold prices are edging up on the back of trade war concerns, with the yellow metal currently at the USD 1,245/oz level. Copper (+0.8%) and nickel (+3.8%) are also seeing some reprieve and have edged up, with copper moving away from year-long lows. Steel has advanced to near 10-month highs as the Chinese Government intensifies efforts to cut pollution is raising supply concerns.

subject: US President Trump says he is in talks with the EU and will meet them next week on trade
US President Trump says their commitment to NATO is very strong
Fed's Mester (Hawkish) says the US economy justifies 2 more rate hikes this year
Eutelsat (ETL FP) has agreed to join a breakthrough proposal started by Intelsat, Intel and SES
RANsquawk EU Mid Session - 12th July 2018 - Conflicting reports on US NATO exit while China throws cold water over trade talks
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

 

EQUITIES

European equities are currently mixed, with the Euro Stoxx 50 essentially flat on the day and consolidating following the losses seen in yesterday’s trade. Equities were slightly choppy amid source reports suggesting that US President Trump was criticising NATO and had threatened to drop out, reports thereafter suggested that pulling out is not on the cards.

The IBEX (-0.2%) and FTSE MIB (-0.3%) are in the red, weighed on by bank stocks with exposure to Turkish assets (BBVA -0.7%) alongside broad-based financial underperformance (UniCredit -1.0%, Banca Generali -1.1%, CaixaBank -1.1%) and possible strike action at Fiat’s (-1.0%) Melfi plant over Cristiano Ronaldo’s transfer cost. Telecom Italia (-1.3%) is also underperforming after a price target cut at Barclays, and is weighing on the telecoms sector, which is currently negative for the day.

The FTSE is outperforming on the back of betting names such as Paddy Power Betfair (+2.7%) benefitting from England’s exit from the World Cup.

Updates on Sky (+1.8%) where Comcast have tabled a GBP 26bln offer to buy the co., moving swiftly to trump Fox’s GBP 24.5bln offer earlier in the week.

Asos (-9.0%) have stated that their guidance for FY18 sales is within +25-30% range and possibly will be toward the lower end of this area.

FX

JPY/AUD - Flanking the G10 list of worst and best performers on less investor angst over a full blown US-China trade war even though the latter (via a Commerce Ministry official) has scotched speculation that the 2 sides have been talking already. Short covering also a factor behind the broad bounce in risk assets and resultant reduced demand for safe-havens like the Jpy that finally yielded to pressure below 111.00 vs the Usd, as the pair broke higher and into a fresh range overnight. Stops are said to have been tripped through 111.50 and major trend-line resistance around 111.57 that had been capping the upside, with more triggered when 112.00 was breached on the way to a circa 112.40 peak. Conversely, the Aud has been able to stem further losses and rebound ahead of 0.7350 vs its US counterpart, although the 0.7400 handle remains elusive.

CHF - Mildly softer vs the Usd as the Franc slips through 0.9950, but still not really behaving like a true port in a currency storm given strict SNB intervention to prevent the highly valued Chf getting too strong.

NZD/GBP/EUR/CAD - All around 0.1-0.15% up on the Greenback, but rangebound with the Kiwi hovering between 0.6750-75, Cable pivoting 1.3200 and awaiting the Brexit White Paper, Eur/Usd trading just below 1.1700 ahead of the ECB minutes and Loonie straddling 1.3200 having lost all and more of its BoC-inspired strength following the tank in oil prices yesterday.

SEK/TRY - Sub-forecast Swedish inflation data and Riksbank minutes highlighting dovish dissenting views have undermined the Krona as the Eur cross climbs to 10.3300 from just over 10.2700 at one stage, but the Lira has regained some composure after slumping to a fresh all time low vs the Usd on Wednesday circa 5.0000 amidst comments from Turkey’s new Treasury and Finance Minister ‘assuring’ CBRT independence and reaffirming pledges to pursue policies that will be fiscally prudent, with single digit inflation and structural reform among the other main priorities. Usd/Try back down around 4.8000.

FIXED INCOME

It remains rather begrudging or at least lacking in conviction, but Bunds and Gilts did stretch the upper end of their intraday ranges to 162.68 and 123.09 (+15 and +16 ticks) before topping out again. No real rationale, though this did coincide with a downturn in BTPs and other peripheral bonds, which looks supply-related in part at least. Conversely, US Treasuries remain depressed and close to overnight session lows ahead of a slew of data, highlighted by CPI that may be skewed to the upside vs consensus in wake of Wednesday’s above forecast PPI. Weekly claims also due after last Friday’s mixed NFP report and the last leg of this week’s auctions in the shape of $14 bn 30 year debt. Note also, some Fed speak via Kashkari and Harker.

COMMODITIES

Oil is recovering this morning after the significant losses seen in yesterday’s trade that was spurred on by trade concerns and increased Libyan production. WTI is up 0.8% and Brent up 1.8% but still well below the levels seen prior to yesterday’s trade, with WTI finding some support at its 100DMA, currently at USD 69.40.

Gold prices are edging up on the back of trade war concerns, with the yellow metal currently at the USD 1,245/oz level. Copper (+0.8%) and nickel (+3.8%) are also seeing some reprieve and have edged up, with copper moving away from year-long lows. Steel has advanced to near 10-month highs as the Chinese Government intensifies efforts to cut pollution is raising supply concerns.

IEA maintain their forecast for 2018 global oil demand growth of 1.4mln BPD, say OPEC crude production in June reached a 4 month high of 31.87mln BPD, up 180k BPD (excl. Congo)

subject: UK debt and STIR futures: narrowly mixed in early Liffe trade
content: A rather subdued and indifferent start to Thursday’s session for Gilts and Short Sterling, with the 10 year benchmark straddling yesterday’s 122.93 Liffe close within a 122.97-89 range, while the 3 month strip has only deviated a tick either side of unchanged. Aside from post-World Cup lethargy and a sombre mood, the lacklustre tone reflects a similar tone on Eurex with Bunds remaining rangebound albeit inching to a marginal new high at 162.59, but still leaving a chart gap up to 162.64 unfilled, according to market contacts looking at near term tech levels. Back to the UK, the BoE credit conditions survey is the sole domestic release, but Brexit will grab the lion’s share of the limelight via the White Paper publication.

Ahead, Eurozone ip forms the main regional data focus, but trumped by US CPI, especially after firmer than forecast PPI, while ECB minutes will be scrutinised for any clearer rate hike guidance vs ‘through’ Summer 2019 that appears to have divided GC members. On the supply front, multi-tranche Italian auctions are due ahead of $14 bn long bonds.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
12th July 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets shrugged off the energy-led declines in US and traded higher across the board with short covering in the region seen after the prior day’s trade-related losses. ASX 200 (+0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) were positive in which the latter coat-tailed on upside in USD/JPY and with Softbank among the biggest gainers after US investment fund Tiger Global took a stake of over USD 1bln in the Co., while broad gains were also seen in Australia aside from commodity-related sectors following recent weakness in the complex including a near-5% drop in crude. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.9%) conformed to the improved risk tone after the PBoC conducted repo operations for the 1st time in over a week and amid continued positive rhetoric regarding A-shares valuations which were said to be at historic lows. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with price action uneventful throughout the session amid focus on riskier assets and with the 20yr auction results largely ignored, despite showing firmer demand and higher accepted prices than previous.      

FTSE

EX-DIVS: Halma (HLMA LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 0.13 points off the FTSE 100

Sky (SKY LN) - Comcast (CMCSA) has tabled a GBP 26bln offer to buy the co., moving swiftly to trump Fox’s GBP 24.5bln offer earlier in the week. (Guardian)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Law firm Leigh Day has launched 1,000 equal pay claims against the co.’s, which could cost the co. about GBP 4bln in compensation. (Guardian)

Unilever (ULVR LN) – A top 5 shareholder in the co. has warned of forced selling over fears about the co.’s HQ move to the Netherlands. (FT)

Glencore (GLEN LN) – The co. is facing at least 2 lawsuits by US shareholders over making false and misleading disclosures prior to receiving its US subpoena in a corruption probe. (Newswires)

BHP Billiton (BLT LN) – The co. has given a proposal for a new labour contact at its Escondida mine in Chile for a wage rise that is linked to inflation, alongside a USD 23k bonus per worker. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 12th July 2018
content:

  • Asian equity markets shrugged off the energy-led declines in US and traded higher across the board

FX markets were flat overnight amid a lack of tier-1 data releases, which kept the DXY at the prior session’s highs

Looking ahead, highlights include Riksbank and ECB minutes, US CPI, weekly jobs figures, supply from Italy and the US

ASIA

Asian equity markets shrugged off the energy-led declines in US and traded higher across the board with short covering in the region seen after the prior day’s trade-related losses. ASX 200 (+0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.2%) were positive in which the latter coat-tailed on upside in USD/JPY and with Softbank among the biggest gainers after US investment fund Tiger Global took a stake of over USD 1bln in the Co., while broad gains were also seen in Australia aside from commodity-related sectors following recent weakness in the complex including a near-5% drop in crude. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.9%) conformed to the improved risk tone after the PBoC conducted repo operations for the 1st time in over a week and amid continued positive rhetoric regarding A-shares valuations which were said to be at historic lows. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with price action uneventful throughout the session amid focus on riskier assets and with the 20yr auction results largely ignored, despite showing firmer demand and higher accepted prices than previous.       

PBoC injected CNY 30bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6726 (Prev. 6.6234)

White House aide stated that US has conducted several high-level talks with China and are open to further discussions. However, there were later conflicting reports that talks between US-China have collapsed following the fresh tariff list and that there were no immediate plans to restart discussions. (Newswires/Twitter)

Bank of Korea kept the 7-Day Repo Rate unchanged at 1.50% as expected, with the decision not unanimous as board member Lee Il-Houng dissented. BoK Governor Lee commented that GDP growth forecast for 2018 was lowered to 2.9% from 3.0% and stated that recent depreciation in KRW against USD was rapid. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May is said to propose a looser relationship with the EU regarding financial services which would reduce access to the European market for UK-based financial firms post-Brexit. (FT)

Hardline Tory Brexiters are looking to try to force UK PM May to publish a rival draft of the white paper drawn up by David Davis in the run-up to last week’s Chequers summit, which Downing Street ditched. (Guardian)

French Finance Minister Le Maire said it is important to look at the impact on the car industry before considering cutting Europe tariffs on car imports. (Newswires)

UK RICS Housing Survey (Jun) 2 vs. Exp. -4 (Prev. -3). (Newswires)

FX

FX markets were flat overnight amid a lack of tier-1 data releases, which kept the DXY at the prior session’s highs seen in the aftermath of the firmer than expected PPI data. This saw its major counterparts languish with EUR/USD stuck at a sub-1.1700 level and with GBP/USD just about holding above 1.3200, while commodity-linked currencies were also softer after the aggressive pull-back in crude prices. Elsewhere, the improved risk appetite spurred outflows from safe-haven JPY, which coupled with the recent USD strength, underpinned USD/JPY to reclaim the 112.00 handle.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were quiet overnight which provided reprieve from the recent trade-triggered pressure. As such, WTI crude futures nursed some losses, although has far to go to make any meaningful recovery from yesterday’s near-5% drop that was attributed to the return of some Libya supply and ongoing trade concerns. Elsewhere, gold is also slightly off prior lows but with upside capped as the greenback held steadfast and copper strengthened amid outperformance of Shanghai metal prices and with China front-running the risk-appetite in the region.
 

Goldman Sachs lowered its copper price 3-month forecast to USD 6500/ton from USD 7300/ton. (Newswires)

US

The treasury complex drifted higher modestly on Wednesday as trade tensions between US and China intensified, with the latter working on alternatives to tariffs retaliation measures to the recently announced US tariffs. In late afternoon trade, Treasuries caught a bid as oil and equities slid. The yield curve further flattened on Wednesday, with yields lower by c.3bps across the curve, with the exception of the 2yr yield which was lower by c.2bps. 2s30s and 2s10s narrowed by c.2bps (the latter fell below 27bps), 2s5s narrowed by c.1bps. US 10YR T-notes futures (u8) settled 7+ ticks higher at 120-08.

Fed's Williams (Voter, Hawkish) said despite strength in equities and house prices, he is not seeing risk taking in financial system of last decade and stated that employers struggling to fill job vacancies which signals a strong economy. (Newswires)

content:

ASX 200 (+0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) are positive with early outperformance in the latter as it coat-tailed on upside in USD/JPY and with Softbank among the biggest gainers after US investment fund Tiger Global took a stake of over USD 1bln in the Co., while broad gains are also seen in Australia aside from commodity related sectors following recent weakness in the complex including a near-5% drop in crude. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) conform to the improved risk tone after the PBoC conducted repo operations for the 1st time in over a week and continued positive rhetoric regarding A-shares valuations, which are said to be at historic lows.

FX markets are flat overnight amid a lack of tier-1 data releases, which has kept the DXY at the prior day’s highs seen in the aftermath of the firmer than expected PPI data that showed wholesale inflation at its highest in 6 years. This saw its major counterparts languish with EUR/USD at a sub-1.1700 level and with GBP/USD struggling to stay above 1.3200, while commodity-linked currencies are also softer after the aggressive pull-back in crude prices. Elsewhere, the improved risk appetite has spurred outflows from safe-haven JPY, which coupled with the recent USD strength, underpinned USD/JPY to reclaim the 112.00 handle.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat with price action uneventful throughout the session so far amid focus on riskier assets and ahead of a 20yr auction later.
